paper_title.ja: 途上国における学童を対象としたフッ化物洗口法の応用とその評価
paper_title.en: Evaluation of Fluoride Mouth-Rinsing Program for Schoolchildren in a Developing Country

description.ja: 著者らは,1989年からネパール王国ラリトプール郡テチョー村において継続的に国際歯科保健医療協力を行っている。この村ではここ数年,都市化に伴う小児の砂糖摂取とう蝕の増加がみられる。そこで,1994年12月から4年間,小児のう蝕予防を目的に,学校でのフッ化物洗口法を実施した。フッ化物洗口法実施の対象は現在,村の7校の学童667名である。方法は0.2%フッ化ナトリウム溶液を用いた週1回洗口法である。採用した実施プログラムは,年間を通して薬剤の調整管理,学校での実施,およびその評価を現地の人が主体的に行う住民参加型プロジェクトである。すなわち,薬剤の管理およびフッ化物洗口液の調整は村内の1ヵ所で行い,1ヵ月分のフッ化物洗口液を配布する。各学校では,毎週同一の曜日に実施する。実施にかかわる担当者の研修は年1回著者らが行った。あわせて事後評価のために,年1回現地スタッフおよび著者らで評価会を開催した。また,現地スタッフは年間3回実施状況についてファクシミリで著者らに報告した。その結果,年間を通したフッ化物洗ロプログラムは,4年間継続して実施された。フッ化物洗口法3年間実施後のう蝕罹患状況では,3年間実施した1校の8〜10歳児でDMFT0.6,DMF者率33.3%であった。それに対して,未実施校3校から抽出した学童では各々0.9,および40.7%であったが,いずれも有意な差はみられなかった。以上の結果から,途上国におけるフッ化物洗口プログラムは,学校保健の育成に効果的であり,住民参加型のプロジェクトとしてネパールのほかの村にも応用でき,地域の施策化につながるものと考えられる。
description.en: Since 1989, we have taken part in an international cooperative effort in the field of dental care in Techo Village, Nepal. The prevalence of dental caries of school children in this village has recently shown an increase due to urbanization and increasing sugar consumption from food, beverages and sweets. The fluoride mouth-rinsing program was performed in December 1994 with 50 children of one primary school. After 4 years, the participants of this program were 667 children of seven primary schools. This program was carried out through weekly mouth-rinsing with 0.2% sodium fluoride solution. The processes of this program, such as preparation of solution, enforcement in each school and evaluation of the operation were performed by citizens of the village that is this program was a project of resident-participation. The training for the fluoride mouth-rinsing program was given to school teachers and local leaders of the village community. This training, performed by Japanese staffmembers, was held once a year. The intended activities of this program were faithfully performed during the 4 year period. With regard to the caries-preventive effect of the weekly fluoride mouth-rinsing program after 3 years, the prevalence rate of dental caries was 33.3% in children aged 8-10 yrs. The DMFT index of 8 to 10 year-old children was 0.6. On the other hand, 40.7% of control participants had dental caries, and the DMFT index was 0.9 in children aged 8-10 yrs. We concluded that this fluoride mouth-rinsing program was very effective in not only prevention of dental caries but also in the area of promoting school health activities in developing countries. This kind of participatory project can increase self-reliance for health. This program might be adopted by other Nepalese villages.

publisher.ja: 一般社団法人 口腔衛生学会

The prevalence of dental caries of school children in this village has recently shown an increase due to urbanization and increasing sugar consumption from food, beverages and sweets. paper_title.ja: 途上国における国際歯科医療協力-ネパール歯科学術調査隊の活動を通して-
ネパール山岳高地住民(ランタン村チベッタン族)の歯科学術的調査
paper_title.en: Dental Survey of Tibetan in Langtang Village, a Highland People of Nepal

description.ja: An investigation of dental diseases in the highlands of Nepal was carried out in Langtang village (3, 500m elevation) from the middle to the end of March of 1992. The people of Langtang village were mostly of the Tamang tribe of Tibetan. This report is related to an epidemiorogical study of this particular tribe. The purpose of this investigation is to understand the dental diseases of Nepali people better. The results obtained were as follows : 1. As for the DMFT of permanent teeth, the DT increased from about 13 years old. Then at the age of over 60 years, it becomes 17.7. The MT is under 1.0 until 50 years old, but it increased dramatically at the age of over 50 years. The incidence of caries affection increased dramatically from about 13 years old and at this age the rate was over 60%. At the age of over 50 years, the incidence became 100%. The FT couldn't be observed. In comparison with the Japanese, the DMFT was very low and its progress was slow. Prior to this survey they received no dental treatments. 2. As for the attrition, attrition score 1 is observed at the ages of 10 to 12 years. According to the aging, number and degree of attrition increased dramatically. 3. The incidence of TMJ is very low in comparison with the people of Thecho village or the Japanese. 4. Few diseases of the soft tissue, except periodontal disease, could be observed. 5. Dental treatments in Langtang village conducted by us were mostly scalling and teeth extraction. We couldn't conduct other treatments, because we didn't have enough equipment and medical staff in there.
description.en: An investigation of dental diseases in the highlands of Nepal was carried out in Langtang village (3, 500m elevation) from the middle to the end of March of 1992. The people of Langtang village were mostly of the Tamang tribe of Tibetan. This report is related to an epidemiorogical study of this particular tribe. The purpose of this investigation is to understand the dental diseases of Nepali people better. The results obtained were as follows : 1. As for the DMFT of permanent teeth, the DT increased from about 13 years old. Then at the age of over 60 years, it becomes 17.7. The MT is under 1.0 until 50 years old, but it increased dramatically at the age of over 50 years. The incidence of caries affection increased dramatically from about 13 years old and at this age the rate was over 60%. At the age of over 50 years, the incidence became 100%. The FT couldn't be observed. In comparison with the Japanese, the DMFT was very low and its progress was slow. Prior to this survey they received no dental treatments. 2. As for the attrition, attrition score 1 is observed at the ages of 10 to 12 years. According to the aging, number and degree of attrition increased dramatically. 3. The incidence of TMJ is very low in comparison with the people of Thecho village or the Japanese. 4. Few diseases of the soft tissue, except periodontal disease, could be observed. 5. Dental treatments in Langtang village conducted by us were mostly scalling and teeth extraction. We couldn't conduct other treatments, because we didn't have enough equipment and medical staff in there.
